verses.text: Whoever loves discipline loves knowledge, but whoever hates correction is stupid.
verses.comment: This verse teaches that loving correction and discipline is a sign of true wisdom. The New Testament reinforces the idea of God's loving discipline in Hebrews 12:6. Openness to correction is essential for growing in holiness, which is a communal and personal journey.

verses.text: A good man obtains favor from the LORD, but the LORD condemns a man of wicked plans.
verses.comment: Here, 'favor' reflects divine grace bestowed upon the upright. The wisdom tradition emphasizes God's just judgment and attentive care for those striving for righteousness.

verses.text: A man cannot be established by wickedness, but the root of the righteous will not be moved.
verses.comment: True stability is spiritual, not just outward. The image of 'root' points to organic, lasting belonging—suggesting deep spiritual life anchored in God's covenant community.

verses.text: An excellent wife is the crown of her husband, but she who brings shame is like rot in his bones.
verses.comment: The analogy of 'crown' conveys dignity and glory given through virtuous partnership. This verse anticipates the high praise of the faithful wife later in Proverbs 31.

verses.text: The thoughts of the righteous are just; the advice of the wicked is deceitful.
verses.comment: The contrast highlights how righteousness affects not only actions but also intentions and inner counsel. Justice originates in the heart.

verses.text: The words of the wicked lie in wait for blood, but the speech of the upright delivers them.
verses.comment: Here, words are shown to have moral weight: evil seeks to destroy, but the righteous use speech to save and protect.

verses.text: The wicked are overthrown and vanish, but the house of the righteous will stand.
verses.comment: Emphasizing ultimate security in God for the righteous—a theme Jesus picks up in the parable of the house on the rock (Matt. 7:24-25).

verses.text: A man is praised according to his wisdom, but one with a warped mind is despised.
verses.comment: Society naturally exalts wisdom; inner disposition, not just outward reputation, determines true honor.

verses.text: Better to be lightly esteemed and have a servant, than to appear important but lack food.
verses.comment: Worth and dignity are not dependent on outward show but on the substance of one’s life. Humility yields lasting provision.

verses.text: The righteous know the needs of their animals, but the kindness of the wicked is cruel.
verses.comment: Caring for creation is a sign of righteousness; even small acts reveal a deeper moral conscience.

verses.text: Whoever works his land will have plenty of bread, but whoever chases empty things lacks sense.
verses.comment: Practical diligence, rooted in faithful stewardship, brings fruitfulness—spiritual as well as material.

verses.text: The wicked desire the stronghold of evildoers, but the root of the righteous produces fruit.
verses.comment: The righteous are marked by lasting fruitfulness—a concept Jesus expanded in John 15:5, teaching on abiding in Him as the true vine.

verses.text: An evil man is trapped by the transgression of his lips, but the righteous will escape from trouble.
verses.comment: Words reveal the heart. This anticipates James 3:2–10, where taming the tongue is seen as key to Christian maturity.

verses.text: From the fruit of his mouth a man is satisfied with good, and the work of a man's hands comes back to him.
verses.comment: Both speech and labor are means of blessing. Speaking good builds up both the self and the community.

verses.text: The way of a fool is right in his own eyes, but a wise man listens to advice.
verses.comment: Humility and teachability are essential virtues, often reinforced in the New Testament call to submit to one another and to Church leadership.

verses.text: A fool’s anger is known at once, but a prudent man ignores an insult.
verses.comment: The prudent control their passions, following the Christ-like path of patience and forgiveness.

verses.text: Whoever speaks truth declares what is right, but a false witness speaks deceit.
verses.comment: This aligns with the moral law, as truthfulness is foundational to justice and right worship.

verses.text: There is one whose rash words are like sword thrusts, but the tongue of the wise brings healing.
verses.comment: The wise imitate God's own healing word, as fulfilled in the life of Christ, the Divine Word made flesh (John 1:14).

verses.text: Truthful lips endure forever, but a lying tongue lasts only a moment.
verses.comment: Eternal values are placed on truth over fleeting deceit, revealing God's enduring nature and the everlasting value of his Word.

verses.text: Deceit is in the heart of those who devise evil, but those who plan peace have joy.
verses.comment: The call to peacemaking is a core virtue, reflected by Jesus in the Beatitudes, calling the peacemakers ‘sons of God.’

verses.text: No harm befalls the righteous, but the wicked are filled with trouble.
verses.comment: Promises of safety often have both literal and spiritual meaning. Ultimate security is found in persevering faithfulness to God.

verses.text: Lying lips are detestable to the LORD, but those who act faithfully are his delight.
verses.comment: Faithfulness, a central theme of both Old and New Covenants, is a characteristic pleasing to God and necessary for participation in His promises.

verses.text: A prudent man keeps knowledge to himself, but the heart of fools proclaims folly.
verses.comment: True wisdom is humble and moderate, echoing the call to humility seen throughout the teaching of Christ.

verses.text: The diligent will rule, but the lazy will be forced to labor.
verses.comment: Industry and stewardship elevate the individual and the community; idleness leads to bondage or servitude.

verses.text: Anxiety in a man's heart weighs him down, but a good word makes him glad.
verses.comment: Words of comfort and encouragement have a healing power, prefiguring the Gospel's call to bear one another's burdens (Gal. 6:2).

verses.text: A righteous man is cautious in friendship, but the way of the wicked leads them astray.
verses.comment: Discernment in relationships is vital for holiness. Fellowship with the virtuous strengthens faith and virtue.

verses.text: The lazy man does not roast what he took in hunting, but diligence is man’s precious possession.
verses.comment: Diligence ensures spiritual and temporal gains are completed and not wasted; perseverance is seen as a spiritual treasure.

verses.text: In the path of righteousness there is life, and in its journey there is no death.
verses.comment: This climactic verse points to the promise of eternal life for the righteous—a hope fulfilled in Jesus, who reveals Himself as 'the way, the truth, and the life.'
